$84.5 million{{cite web|last1=Schilling|first1=Mark|title=‘Frozen’ outlasts ‘Eternal’ at Japan box office|url=http://variety.com/2014/film/news/frozen-outlasts-eternal-at-japan-box-office-1201157455/|website=Variety|publisher=Variety|accessdate=2 September 2014}} }} {{Nihongo|'''''The Eternal Zero'''''|永遠の0|Eien no Zero}} is a 2013 Japanese [[war film|war]] [[drama film]] directed by [[Takashi Yamazaki]] and based on a novel by [[Naoki Hyakuta]], published in English by [[Vertical Inc.]].{{cite web |url= http://www.filmbiz.asia/news/eternal-zero-claims-number-one-spot-in-japan|title= Eternal Zero claims number one spot in Japan|author= Kevin Ma|date= 24 December 2013|accessdate= 8 January 2014|work= [[Film Business Asia]]}}{{cite web |url= http://eiga.com/movie/58291/|script-title=ja:永遠の0|accessdate= 8 January 2014|work= eiga.com|language= Japanese}} ==Plot== [[File:A6M3 Zero N712Z.jpg|thumb|180px|right|Zero fighter plane]] In 2004, twenty-six-year-old Kentaro Saeki is repeatedly failing the [[Attorneys in Japan#Qualification|national bar examination]] and is uncertain about his future. One day, after the [[funeral]] of his grandmother, Matsuno, he is startled to learn from his mother and older sister Keiko that his maternal grandfather Kenichiro was not his blood-relation. Keiko and Kentaro start hearing stories about their real grandfather, Kyuzo Miyabe and visit many of his former comrades all of whom begin by criticize his "timidity" in battle. Kentaro finally learns the reason why Miyabe became a [[Kamikaze|Kamikaze pilot]] during the conversation with an old comrade of his grandfather called Izaki, who is in hospital dying of cancer. Izaki talks about his relationship with their grandfather to Keiko and Kentaro, claiming that only the "timid" Miyabe gave him the hope to save his own life after he was shot down over the ocean. The film begins with an unspecified attack near the end of the [[Pacific War]], a [[Mitsubishi A6M Zero|Zero fighter plane]] threatens the [[United States Pacific Fleet]] by cutting through its defensive anti-aircraft fire. Kyuzo Miyabe, the pilot of the Zero fighter is regarded by his comrades as a coward, though an exceptionally skilled fighter pilot, for consistently returning alive from missions, openly explaining "I don't want to die," the result of a promise made to his wife Matsuno and daughter Kiyoko: to return from the war alive. After the [[attack on Pearl Harbor]] in 1941, the [[Imperial Japanese Navy]] advances steadily, only to be steadily beaten hollow in the battles from [[Battle of Midway]] and [[Bombing of Rabaul (November 1943)|Bombing on Rabaul]] onwards. Despite the rising desperation and hopelessness of their situation, all of Miyabe's men say they wish to die gloriously in battle. However, he persuades them, by his simple and honest example (Miyabe accepts severe beatings by outraged senior officers several times for speaking these opinions, and refuses to retract them), that to survive is worthwhile. Both Keiko and Kentaro still are puzzled as to why their grandfather - eventually - volunteers for [[Kamikaze|Kamikaze Attack]]. Kentaro, now obsessed with finding the answer, spends much time researching the war. At a blind dinner date with several friends, he becomes incensed when one compares the Kamikaze pilots with suicide bombers and storms off. He continues talking with Miyabe's most reticent and intimidating comrade in arms, now the head of a Yakuza-linked, right-wing group, and finds the man willing to explain his own story, which begins to explain this puzzle. He and his sister then learn the details and unfolding of the promise between Miyabe and their living grandfather Kenichiro before the final mission. Miyabe is said by his wife to have kept his promise, by insuring that many worthy lives were not pointlessly lost and by providing his wife and child with Kenichiro, who becomes a loving husband and father. One summer day in 1945, Kyuzo Miyabe boards a Zero fighter but then asks Kenichiro if he can "make a selfish request" and change planes with him. Kenichiro's plane develops engine trouble and he has to return, leaving Miyabe alone in attack on an [[Essex-class aircraft carrier]] - (in reality an aircraft carrier, CV 17, the USS Bunker Hill was damaged by kamikaze attack during the battle for Okinawa. In the final moments of the film as the plane dives at the carrier the number 14 is visible on the deck. CV 14, the USS Ticonderoga, was in reality hit by a kamikaze on January 21, 1945). The film ends with a calm Miyabe about to crash into the ship. ==Cast== *[[Junichi Okada]] as Kyuzo Miyabe *[[Haruma Miura]] as Kentaro Saeki *[[Mao Inoue]] as Matsuno *[[Kazue Fukiishi]] as Keiko Saeki *[[Jun Fubuki]] as Kiyoko Saeki *[[Isao Natsuyagi]] as Kenichiro Ōishi *[[Shōta Sometani]] as young Kenichiro *[[Isao Hashizume]] as Izaki *[[Gaku Hamada]] as young Izaki *[[Min Tanaka]] as Kageura *[[Hirofumi Arai]] as young Kageura *[[Mikijirō Hira]] as Hasegawa *[[Tatsuya Ueda]] *[[Yuya Endo]] *[[Rakuto Tochihara]] ==Production== This film is based on a novel of the same name by [[Naoki Hyakuta]]. However, director Yamazaki and scriptwriter Tamio Hayashi had to edit the original story and remove many of the novel's characters and scenes. Yamazaki said that the production team had "really struggled at the script stage, trying to extract the essence of the novel." Hyakuta himself did not express any objections to the final film script.{{cite web |url= http://www.scmp.com/lifestyle/arts-culture/article/1508179/flights-fancy-box-office-smash-eternal-zero-reopens-old |title= http://www.scmp.com/lifestyle/arts-culture/article/1508179/flights-fancy-box-office-smash-eternal-zero-reopens-old |author= Mark Schilling|date= May 11, 2014|accessdate= June 3, 2014|work= [[South China Morning Post]]}} With regards to casting, Yamazaki said that they had cast actors on "the basis of whether they were right for the role, not their popularity". He also said that the crew wanted "young actors who had something of the atmosphere of that time about them". Specifically, Yamazaki referred to Okada, saying that "He was extremely close to our image of Miyabe". He further elaborated by saying that "In the film the character knows martial arts, so Okada studied hard. He got so much into it that he became a shihan [qualified teacher].". He praised Okada as a guy "who's really thorough when he focuses on one thing." The film uses [[Computer-generated imagery]] to replicate the scenes of bombing runs and dogfights, given the limitation of having a tiny number of zero fighters being in a flyable condition having survived till the present day. ==Reception== As of early January 2014, the film had grossed [[Japanese yen|¥]]3.21 billion ([[United States dollar|US$]]30.8 million) at the Japanese box office.{{cite web |url= http://www.filmbiz.asia/news/eternal-zero-tops-japans-new-years-bo|title= Eternal Zero tops Japan's New Year's B.O.|author= Kevin Ma|date= 8 January 2014|accessdate= 8 January 2014|work= [[Film Business Asia]]}} By January 19, it had grossed ¥5.17 billion (US$49.45 million).{{cite web |url= http://www.tokyohive.com/article/2014/01/japan-box-office-report-01-1801-19|title= Japan Box Office Report – 01/18~01/19|date= January 22, 2014|accessdate= January 23, 2014|work= tokyohive|publisher= 6Theory Media, LLC.}} By the end of January it had grossed ¥5.89 billion (US$57.3 million).{{cite web |url= http://www.filmbiz.asia/news/eternal-zero-leads-japan-bo-for-sixth-weekend|title= Eternal Zero leads Japan B.O. for sixth weekend|author= Kevin Ma|date= 29 January 2014|accessdate= 29 January 2014|work= [[Film Business Asia]]}} The film had grossed ¥6.5 billion (US$64.1 million) about a month and a half after being released. It matched the last record for a Japanese [[live action]] film with seven successive weeks at number one with ''[[Hero (2007 film)|Hero]]'' (2007).{{cite web |url= http://www.filmbiz.asia/news/thor-and-wolf-fail-to-dethrone-eternal-zero|title= Thor and Wolf fail to dethrone Eternal Zero|author= Kevin Ma|date= 5 February 2014|accessdate= 6 February 2014|work= [[Film Business Asia]]}} With more than seven weeks in cinemas, it had grossed ¥6.98 billion.{{cite web |url= http://www.filmbiz.asia/news/eternal-zero-tops-japan-bo-for-8th-week|title= Eternal Zero tops Japan B.O. for 8th week|author= Kevin Ma|date= February 13, 2014|accessdate= February 13, 2014|work= [[Film Business Asia]]}} The film earned {{JPY|8.76 billion}} at the Japanese box office, becoming the 2nd highest-grossing Japanese film of 2013 in the country and the 3rd highest-grossing film of the year in the country.{{cite web |url= http://www.eiren.org/toukei/img/eiren_kosyu/data_2014.pdf|title= ２０１４年 （平成２６年） 全国映画概況|accessdate= October 31, 2015|work= eiren.org|publisher= Motion Picture Producers Association of Japan, Inc.|language= Japanese}}{{cite web |url= http://www.boxofficemojo.com/intl/japan/yearly/?yr=2013&p=.htm|title= Japan Yearly Box Office 2013|accessdate= October 31, 2015|work= [[Box Office Mojo]]}} ''The Eternal Zero'' won the Golden Mulberry, the top audience award, at the 16th [[Udine Far East Film Festival]] in Italy.{{cite web |url= http://variety.com/2014/film/news/eternal-zero-wins-udine-audience-prize-1201171158/|title= Japanese Pic ‘Eternal Zero’ Wins Italy’s Udine Audience Prize|author= Mark Schilling|date= May 3, 2014|accessdate= June 3, 2014|work= ''[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]''}} The film will be released in [[Taiwan]] on 12 September 2014.{{citation needed|date=June 2014}} {{expand section|1=Japan Academy Awards coverage, noms and wins |date=January 2016}} ==Controversy== ''The Eternal Zero'' has come under criticism for its nationalistic and sympathetic depiction of the Kamikaze pilots.{{cite web |url= http://news.usni.org/2014/04/14/japanese-eyes-world-war-ii-japanese-cinema |title= Through Japanese Eyes: World War II in Japanese Cinema |date= April 14, 2014|accessdate= June 3, 2014|work= [[US Naval Academy]]}} Director [[Hayao Miyazaki]] in an interview accused the film of "trying to make a Zero fighter story based on a fictional war account that is a pack of lies". He added that this film was "just continuing a phony myth" and that he had "hated that sort of thing ever since [I] was a kid." [[Kazuyuki Izutsu]], the director of the 2005 film ''[[Break Through!|Pacchigi!]]'' said that the film had "no basis in fact". The film has also courted controversy amongst Japan's neighbors, especially China, with one Chinese commentator reportedly accusing the film of being "propaganda for terrorism".{{cite web |url= http://www.japantimes.co.jp/culture/2014/02/20/films/debate-still-rages-over-abe-endorsed-wwii-drama/#.U40-OyhdBGU |title= Debate still rages over Abe-endorsed WWII drama |author= Mark Schilling |date= February 20, 2014|accessdate= June 3, 2014|work= [[The Japan Times]]}} However, the film's director, Takashi Yamazaki, rejected these interpretations of the film, saying, "The film depicts the war as a complete tragedy, so how can you say it glorifies war?... I really don't get it." He eventually dismissed such criticism, saying that "In the end, people see what they want to see. If you think from the start that 'this movie glorifies war' you're going to see it as a movie that glorifies war, no matter what." Similarly, the author of the original book, Naoki Hyakuta, disagreed with this line of criticism, stating in a [[Twitter|tweet]] that "In my book ''Eternal Zero'', I opposed suicide attacks with determination", "I have never ever viewed wars in a positive light", and the theme of the book was "not to allow our memories of war to fade away".{{Cite web |title = （楽屋ハナシ）百田尚樹×山崎貴 幸せって何だろう |url = http://www.asahi.com/articles/ASF0TKY201312280175.html |publisher = 朝日新聞デジタル | date = 2013-12-30 |accessdate = 2014-01-28 }} The author also added in a [[Twitter|tweet]], "I feel sorry for ''Eternal Zero''. [...] On one side of the political spectrum, Japanese right-wing nationalists claimed the book was plagiarized and were indignant about its criticism of high-ranking Japanese government officials, while on the opposite side, left-wingers criticized it as a glorification of war, [[Hayao Miyazaki]] rebukes it for fabrication [...]. It is drawing fire literally from all directions." Yet the book and the film have been warmly received by its Japanese audiences: the film was one of the highest-grossing films of the year in Japan. Notably, [[Shinzo Abe]], the Prime Minister of Japan, declared his support for this film and the book, saying that he had been "moved" by it. [[Yoko Ono]] also dedicated a special message to the brochure of the film, expressing her concurrence to the message of the film.Official brochure of the film ''Eien no Zero'' (2013). p.40, Tokyo: Toho Pictures Inc. Visual Department. Critics have accused the film of misrepresenting Kamikaze pilots. They argued that instead of the pilots being willing to sacrifice themselves for Japan as depicted in the film, these pilots were actually forced to take part in these suicide missions.{{cite web |url= http://www.economist.com/news/asia/21597946-film-about-kamikaze-pilots-gives-worrying-boost-nationalists-mission-accomplished |title= Japan’s right wing: Mission accomplished? |date= March 1, 2014|accessdate= June 3, 2014|work= [[The Economist]]}} ==Other media== In June 2014, [[TV Tokyo]] announced that the station would adapt the film for a TV drama featuring [[Osamu Mukai]]. Some parts in the original book which don't appear in the film are described in the drama. It was broadcast on 11, 14 and 15 February 2015.{{Cite web |script-title=ja:【スペシャルドラマ】 永遠の０(ゼロ) |url = http://www.tv-tokyo.co.jp/official/tx_drama_eienno-zero/ |publisher = ''[[TV Tokyo]]'' | date = |accessdate = 2014-06-08 |language= Japanese }} The film will be issued on [[DVD]] and [[Blu-ray Disc|BD]] in Japan on 23 July 2014.{{Cite web |title = 永遠の0 Blu-ray/DVD 7月23日発売 |url = http://www.eienno-zero.jp/bddvd/ |publisher = | date = |accessdate = 2014-06-08 |language= Japanese }} ==See also== *[[Imperial Japanese Navy Air Service]] ==References== {{reflist|28em}} ==External links== * {{Official website|http://www.eienno-zero.jp/index.html}} * {{IMDb title|2404217}} {{Takashi Yamazaki}} {{Japan Academy Prize for Best Film}} {{Nikkan Sports Film Award for Best Film}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Eternal Zero, The}} [[Category:2010s drama films]] [[Category:2010s war films]] [[Category:2013 films]] [[Category:Japanese drama films]] [[Category:Japanese films]] [[Category:Japanese war films]] [[Category:Films directed by Takashi Yamazaki]] [[Category:Films based on Japanese novels]] [[Category:Toho films]] [[Category:War drama films]] [[Category:Japanese aviation films]]
